name_origin.etymology: The term 'Shawarma' (שווארמה) is an Arabized corruption of the Ottoman Turkish word 'çevirme' (pronounced che-vir-meh), which means 'turning' or 'rotating,' referring to the vertical rotisserie cooking method. The suffix 'Soya' (סויה) is a Modern Hebrew loanword (ultimately from Japanese 'shoyu' via Dutch/English) indicating the vegetarian protein base. While the dish appears in a Djerban context here, the name and concept are Modern Israeli adaptations of Levantine street food, not traditional North African Jewish cuisine.
name_origin.sources_notes: Standard culinary etymology. The Turkish 'çevirme' became the Arabic 'shawarma' (changing the 'ch' to 'sh'). It is important to note that this is a modern 'pareve' (neutral) adaptation, likely created to allow the consumption of a shawarma-style dish within a dairy meal or for vegetarians, rather than a historical Djerban dish.

alternative_names.name: Chawarma Végétarienne
alternative_names.notes: Common nomenclature in modern Tunisia and France

similar_dishes.name: Döner Kebab
similar_dishes.similarity: The original meat-based dish cooked on a vertical rotisserie.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Made with lamb or beef; the 'soy' version is pan-seared rather than roasted on a spit.

similar_dishes.name: Gyros
similar_dishes.similarity: Vertical rotisserie meat dish derived from the same Ottoman tradition.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Often made with pork or chicken and served with tzatziki (yogurt), which is forbidden in kosher meat meals (though permissible with this soy version).

similar_dishes.name: Shawarma
similar_dishes.similarity: The meat-based street food this dish emulates.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses layers of fat and meat (lamb, turkey, chicken) rather than textured vegetable protein.
